title: girl 6 given 50 chance
story: Girl, , given % chance of survival after tummy ache turned out to be rare cancerIsabelle Grundy, six, was diagnosed with a High Risk, Stage  Neuroblastoma as her parents are desperately seeking to fly to New York for treatment that could help her live longerIsabelle Grundy has been diagnosed with a High Risk, Stage  Neuroblastom, which comes with a  per cent survival rate Image: Lancs Live WSByFatima AzizAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA young schoolgirl has been given a % chance of survival after her sore tummy turned out to be an aggressive and rare form of cancer. Isabelle Grundy, six, has been battling cancer for six months, and her parents are desperately seeking treatment from abroad.The youngster, from Thornton Cleveleys, was a happy little girl before her le-changing diagnosis in the summer of , LancsLive reports. Isabelle woke up complaining to mum Louisa Moss that she had a sore tummy and she was off school with a suspected bug. Her condition became worse throughout the day and Louisa found a lump on the left side of her stomach. Louisa, , said: It was quite sudden, previous to this day, I noticed she was tired but I canapost say that she was ill- when itaposs your own kids you pick up very quicklyitaposs anything more. This lump that I found in Isabelleaposs tummy it wasnapost an obvious lump and not somewhere you would go poking and prodding - I just couldnapost believe it. I kind of knew when I felt the lump and did a bit of research, I knew then and there that it wasnapost going to be good news - at the same time I was doubting myself thinking no it canapost be because of how well sheaposs been. Isabelle was seen by GPs, hospitals and specialists before she was diagnosed with a High Risk, Stage  Neuroblastoma. Such a diagnosis comes with a  per cent survival rate.A week later, she was enduring a world of appointments, therapies and treatments all before she even turned six. Since her diagnosis, Isabelle has undergone a lot of intensive treatment, ranging from high dose chemotherapy, numerous cannulas, MIBG Scans, CT scans, ultrasound scans as well as several blood and platelet transfusions. She has also undergone a high-risk surgery where only a small section of Isabelle’s tumour was safely removed through stem cell harvest and transplant. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email.After  days worth of chemotherapy and five additional days of intense chemotherapy, it seemed she was responding positively to each treatment. However, just before Christmas and her birthday, Isabelle was sent to the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit after quickly becoming severely poorly once again. Louisa said: On the rd of December, we just knew she wasnapost right, her tummy was distended, she needed to go to the toilet but couldnapost pass any urine. She just looked so poorly, she was wanting to sleep a lot- she went for an ultrasound on Christmas Eve morning and they found she was full of fluid. Isabelle spent Christmas and New Yearaposs in a hospital bed - not being able to open her presents. The mum added: It was heartbreaking, it was awful. It was just me and Isabelleaposs big brother on Christmas morning so we Facetimed daddy and Isabelle was completely oblivious. She was fast asleep at the time which she was like the majority of the time. We have such a big family so not seeing any our family at Christmas was hard - we didnapost want them to come up here because of Covid we just had to be so careful who we were mixing with. We canapost really say it was Christmas at all, it was just horrible. Isabelle still has a  per cent survival rate as her family are looking for other options abroad. They found a vaccination that is given in New York and it can reduce the risk of the cancer ing and will increase her chances of living a longer le. However, it will cost at least £, to get there and to receive the treatment over the course of more than two years. To help out, a family friend has set up a JustGiving page which has, in just over two weeks, managed to rake up more than £,.To donate to Isabelleaposs fundraiser, click here. news uk-news hilarious-moment-woman-loses-after-"Woman loses After Eight game owing to forehead botoxByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsA woman had her family in stitches of laughter when she struggled to play the After Eight game because she could not move her Botox-filled forehead. Charlotte Taundry, , was playing the confectionary-based game over the New Year with partner Sarah Hutchison, , as well as their friends and family. But when it was her turn to play the game - in which players try to move one of the chocolates from their heads to their mouths without using their hands- she had to admit defeat. Speaking afterwards she explained it was because, try as she might, she could not move her face muscles because of the temporary face paralyser.In a video Sarah can be heard laughing hysterically as Charlotte, who she met on ITV ’s The Cabins, tries to move the choccie treat which refuses to budge.Charlotte, a trainee dietician, said: When that video was filmed Iaposd already been doing it five minutes. It just wasnapost happening. I just kept thinking, aposI look awfulapos - pulling the most stupid facial expressions. “But it was so funny, I had to do it. I was wiping my tears away I was laughing that much. “Hopefully it give some people a laugh. Sarah added: “I was just creasing laughing. We both have botox. We canapost tell when we’re annoyed at each other - itaposs great.  But she was determined and stuck it on her head. I watched everyone  get it to their mouth - [while Charlotte] sat there squinting and squeezing her face. It comes as the happy couple announced recently they are planning on starting IVF as they want a family.They told The Sun Charlotte will carry the baby.She said: “We know where we are going to go with it in a few years time. I’m obviously  now, so approaching the age where we need to start thinking about children. We’ve thought about stuff like that [IVF], we haven’t got an exact plan in mind but we know over the next few years it’s definitely where we are going. news uk-news kate-middleton-coming-own-ready-"Kate Middleton releases photographs to mark th birthdayByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments While the photo that snatched the headlines this weekend was dynamic Kate at  in sizzling red, it was the subtler profile shot in white which spoke a thousand words about the Duchess’s burgeoning royal status.While her profile is delicate, her expression soft as the tulle of her dress, and her curls whimsically blowing in the breeze of a wind machine, there is a strength about the romantic photograph which shouts queen-in-waiting.  The pose is far from new. It is one which has been used repeatedly down the decades to capture a young princess or duchess coming of age, their elegant footing firm on the path to queendom. As well as by female monarchs well established in their reign. Queen Victoria, Queen Mary, the Queen Mother, Princess Margaret, Diana, even Princess Grace of Monaco, not to mention our current Queen, have struck similar poses. The combination of romanticism and regality is recognisable straightaway as Kate holds a mirror to former eras. Royal commentator Ingrid Seward explains: “In this image I think you see a nod to Kate rising up the ranks. People look at her and see the perfect queen, young and beautul. “It evokes an image of the Queen as a young woman and even conjures up historically a Boadicea, strong, yet feminine - femininity yet strength. “That idealised image of a young queen, serene, in control and poised.” She adds: “Kate is coming into her own. She is genuinely involved in her charity work, which will be her legacy. “We have seen her in the peacemaker role between William and Harry, we saw her at the carol concert in Westminster stepping confidently into the spotlight, she is no longer a clothes horse, there is a strength there now. “We can see Kate stepping up a level, the coming of a queen in waiting, and I think she is more ready to fill those shoes.” But she stresses the Duchess will no doubt feel embarrassed by the attention on her position. She’s been in The Firm long enough to know she must not overstep the mark. “Prince Charles is not even King yet and the Royals are very careful about not upstaging each other. Kate will be keen not to upstage Camilla,” says Ingrid. “She is aware of hierarchy and that it is Camilla’s turn. “But she is a wonderful advert for the monarchy, especially globally, and people will see her as the perfect queen.”  Platinum puddings By Tyrese ChinDenCoy What better way to celebrate the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee this year than with cake  Her Maj has decreed a Royal Bake Off, asking the nation to come up with a pud we can all raise a spoon to. Fortnum and Mason and The Big Jubilee Lunch invite Britain’s bakers, aged eight and above, to create a dish that can be replicated across the country to celebrate the -year milestone.  Five finalists will have the chance to bake their dishes at Fortnum’s store in Piccadilly to be judged by Dame Mary Berry, palace head chef Mark Flanagan and Masterchef list Monica Galetti. Why not take some inspiration from Royal favourites, old or new  From Prince William’s chocolate biscuit cake to Henry the VIII’s favourite red wine and ginger jelly or Queen Victoria’s famous Victoria Sponge, they’re a family of sweet tooths. Henry VIII Favourite Food: Jelly Hippocras. Henry VIII was a large man and would often have over  freshly cooked dishes served for him every day. He loved his red wine and even built two fountains which spouted hundreds of gallons of the stuff for him and his courtiers to enjoy everyday. Alongside it, Henry particularly liked this jelly which included wine, ginger and cinnamon. Victoria I Favourite Food: Victoria Sponge Cake Queen Victoria was someone who enjoyed eating and was said to have had a hearty appetite. She enjoyed sweet foods from ice-creams to pastries, and cake so much that the Victoria Sponge was named after her. Duchess Kate Favourite Food: Sticky Toffee Pudding Kate’s fav foods reportedly include sushi and Italian - the latter because it’s easy to cook with ther kids and let them get their hands messy. But when it comes to favourite puds it’s a spongy Sticky Toffee Pudding. Prince William Favourite Food: Chocolate biscuit cake The Duke is a big fan of chocolate biscuit cakes, so much so the cake was served at his wedding. William’s fondness for the cake apparently comes from a specic recipe which he learnt from his grandmother, the Queen. title: man detained public after trying
story: Man detained by public after trying to lead girl, , from family in pubCheshire Police say a -year-old man approached the girl in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire before he was challenged by a parent and othersA -year-old man approached the four-year-old child in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire, police said Image: MEN MediaByTom DuffyAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A man was detained by the public after allegedly trying to lead a young girl from a pub. A -year-old man approached the four-year-old child in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Middlewich, Cheshire and tried to lead her away, police said. A parent then challenged the man and other members quickly detained him at the scene. It happened at about pm on Saturday and police have since arrested a -year-old man on suspicion of child abduction. He remains in custody. A spokesperson for Cheshire Constabulary said: Police have arrested a -year-old man from Middlewich following a report of a child abduction in Middlewich.  At pm on Saturday  January a man approached a four-year-old girl in The Cheshire Cheese pub in Lewin Street, Middlewich and tried to lead her away. He was challenged by a parent, and members of the public detained him outside the pub to prevent him from leaving the area. The girl was thankfully physically unharmed by the incident. Police subsequently arrested a man on suspicion of child abduction. He remains in custody. Chief Inspector Claire Jesson said: “While this was very concerning incident, this was isolated and the suspect was swtly arrested. “I’d like to thank those who intervened and prevented the suspect from leaving the area. “We have increased patrols to provide reassurance and the family are being supported by officers.”Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Cheshire Police" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man loses 70lb without stepping
story: Man loses lb without stepping foot in gym and while enjoying regular mealsGavin Quinn, who writes for the Irish Mirror, shed the huge amount of weight in seven months while also rewarding himself with some snacks along the wayGavin Quinn before his weight loss Image: Belfast Live WSByGavin QuinnSports reporterGraeme Murray:,  Jan | commentsA man who lost lb without setting foot in a gym has shared his weight loss secrets. Gavin Quinn, a sports reporter, lost five stone in seven months with regular meals and exercise. The feat is even more astonishing because he did not once go to the gym during his weight loss journey. He puts his remarkable loss down to a combination of diet and exercise. Gavin, who writes for the Irish Mirror, shed the weight in seven months, but rewarded himself with some snacks along the way. BelfastLive reports that he had started to gain weight when he was a teenager.He said: I lost  poundsin seven months after deciding to make a change in October .Tipping the scales at around  stone, I wasnapost massively overweight but Iaposd noticed a gradual increase since I was a teenager that was accelerated by the initial Covid- lockdown.I looked into what I was eating and slowly turned around my diet and found cycling as a great way to get active to complement the changes Iaposd made. By Christmas I had lost over two stone and I kept it up in the New Year before hitting the five stone mark in May .  Gavinaposs weight continued to fall to  stoneand he eased off and worked on fitness goals rather than weight. He said for some people this was an epiphany moment similar to a favourite shirt no longer fitting them. Gavin added: But for me it was just a culmination of all the right things, I donapost have any overriding reason for making a change. At the time Ireland was staring at another Covid- lockdown which lasted seven months. Iaposd tried almost all of the aposfad dietsapos to no avail in the months and years before, and I could just feel my confidence was at an all-time-low, Gavin added. And on October , a Sunday morning, I said to myself that I need to make a change and that day would be day one. He tackled his eating and sleeping habits first and establishing a structure to his diet. Gavin gave himself a simple plan to start off with get eight hours sleep and have three meals a day at roughly the same time of day.  I set myself a rough target of , daily calories and used apps such as MyFitnessPal to help track what I was eating, Gavin added. Initially I didnapost pay too much attention to my macro-nutrients, but made an effort to ensure I was drinking plenty of water, eating foods with high fibre, vitamins and lower fat counts - particularly saturated fats. This meant I still had treats and snacks to enjoy, but the small changes slowly begin to add up and the , calories I consumed each day began to feel like more and more as the days and weeks went by. Some days it was , calories and other days it was , calories - donapost beat yourself up over going over your allowance every once in a while. Itaposs not about cutting yourself off from food, but rather improving your relationship with food.  The amazing thing about Gavinaposs weight loss was he did not join a gym. He never had great interest in the gym and hadnapost done when he was younger. Personally, I never took to the gym when I was younger and always liked to exercise as a means of engaging in a sport or activity, Gavin said. Gyms can be intimidatingyouaposve never become a member, but Iaposd suggest anybody looking to get active consider it. For me, I found a means to exercise in cycling - which has grown into somewhat of a passion for me over the past  months. Here are more of Gavinaposs aposs top tips on how he did it, from his diet to level of exercise:How did you manage your diet It can be dficult to follow a calorie deficit, when youaposre consuming less calories than youaposre burning your body is being forced to eat into fat reserves to fill that void. I made sure not to overdo it - deliberately eating just , calories per day can be too much and you could risk reverting back to old ways. Having my breakfast and lunches at very similar timeshelped build early eating habits that would set me up for the day. Again to ensure I wasnapost completely flipping my diet completely I used a degree of leniency when it came to dinner time, small changes like portion control and avoiding fatty foods when you have the option can make all the dference. Initially I found myself eating a lot of the same foods I already had, particularly snacks, but doing so meant Iaposd simply be eating less of what I used to rather than eating right. After the first week I began replacing some snack foods with lower calorie snacks, which in turn meant I had more calories to play with for my substantial meals. If I was eating a pack of  calorie crisps, Iaposd replace them with  calorie crisps, swap the Cadbury chocolate bars for lower calorie rice cake bars, treating myself to a zero calorie fizzy drink rather than a full sugar alternative. This meant I still had treats and snacks to enjoy, but the small changes slowly begin to add up and the , calories I consumed each day began to feel like more and more as the days and weeks went by. Some days it was , calories and other days it was , calories - donapost beat yourself up over going over your allowance every once in a while. Itaposs not about cutting yourself off from food, but rather improving your relationship with food.What are your favoured foods for weight loss Iaposve found so many great foods the past  months that I never enjoyed before, and Iaposd be confident in saying my relationship with food has really grown as I became more aware of what I was putting into my body. Hereaposs some of my favoured foods these days: Cous Cous: I sometimes use it as a lighter alternative to rice, itaposs easy to make and is high in carbohydrates and fibre.Rice crispy bars: Excellent for a quick snack, theyaposre a lot better than a bar of chocolate.Lentil curls: A low calorie alternative to many brands of crisps, Iaposve grown to love them.Nuts and seeds: A great snack, good source of protein and fats.Turkey burgers: Lean, high in protein and delicious - no explanation needed.Vegetables: Whatever they are eat plenty of them, theyaposre good for you and should be an essential pillar of your diet. Did you give up takeaways and alcohol Not really. Weaposve always had a aposTakeaway Fridayapos at home so I made sure to allow myself the Friday treat. Although instead of chips in the chinese takeaway some weeks Iaposd get rice or even eat a smaller portion. I initially gave up alcohol until Christmas, but when I did drink I opted for lower calorie light beers or spirits more often than not instead of calorie-dense lagers or stout.Do you need support to lose weight Everybody needs support when undertaking such a big change. Whether that be a personal trainer, or just a family member or close friend, Iaposd recommend you get someone on board to be there for support. In my case, I asked a close friend to act almost like my aposcoachapos to keep me honest. He would get in touch every now and then to see how I was getting on, was there to listenI had problems and cheer me on to my goals. Needless to say that educated professionals are much more qualied to play such a role, but having someone to bounce off and hold you accountable on the journey is essential.Did you almost give up Yeah, I came pretty close on November . I was making good progress in the weeks before but that morning I weighed in after a particularly tough week and had lost just one pound. In hindsight losing a pound in a week is a good achievement, but that week had been so dficult and the loss was a lot lower than I was expecting. I was agitated and questioning what I was doing for hours before I was convinced to take an hour to go on a short cycle to clear my mind. If I hadnapost walked out to get some headspace I wouldaposve broken and dialled back weeks of progress, especially since Iaposd already been fully committed to nearly a month. If youaposre about to give in - take a step back and remember why youaposre doing it.What do you doyou lose motivation Some days you just wake up and the same motivation you initially had just isnapost there - itaposll happen to everybody. Of course motivation is great, but it comes and goes. Behind the motivation you do need to have a certain amount of discipline. It can be very tough but you need discipline for when the inspiration and motivation just isnapost there. Weekly goals can help keep you focused.When did you start to see results The real goal wasnapost to get down to a certain weight or number, it was to feel good and take back some confidence that Iaposd probably lost. I started to notice a dference in how I looked around Christmas time , but had already felt better after about  days or so. I tipped the scales initially every week but increased that to twice weekly to avoid any discouraging fluctuations. Weighing yourself can be a good way of mapping out progress, but itaposs not the most important. If youaposre not getting the expected results one week, donapost get discouraged, itaposs important to make sure to keep doing the right things - the results will come.How important was exercise to your weight loss Quite important. I found a passion in cycling during my weight loss journey, but any form of exercise can give you similar results. Some people like running, walking, playing certain sports or of course the gym. It really doesnapost matter what your form of exercise is,you have a healthy and balanced diet then exercise is your best friend. Think of it as a complimentary relationship, the old saying of you cant out-exercise a bad diet can also be true for having a healthy diet but sitting on the couch all day. As little as a walk in the park, a short hike, leisurely bike ride or a dip in the sea can compliment whatever calories deficits youaposre creating and help you reach your goals faster. Butyou are taking on more rigorous exercise, itaposs important to ensure you arenapost creating too large of a deficit and are re-fuelling adequately.What are your golden rules for weight loss Everyone has their golden rules for weight loss, and although these particularly rules wonapost work for everyone, hereaposs a couple of mine: - Calorie deficit: If you create a daily calorie deficit, you will lose weight. Itaposs simple when you break it down like that. - Always treat yourself: Itaposs not about burning your bridges with certain foods, itaposs about improving your relationship with food. - Take your time: Thereaposs no rush, everyoneaposs bodies are dferent and once youaposre moving in the right direction thataposs all that matters. - Find your support network: Find someone to keep you on the right path and hold you accountable in the long run. - Exercise: Doesnapost matter what it is, get out there and get active. - Listen to your body: If youaposre hungry, eat something. If youaposre over-exercising, rest.Whataposs your advice to someone hoping to start their own journey If you were to take one thing from reading this, it would be my real golden rule. Sustainability. Whatever habits, calorie deficits or exercise regimes youaposre trying to put in place - you have to ask yourselfitaposs sustainable. When I set out to lose some weight, the one huge dference between all my failed attempts in the past was I asked myself is it sustainable  You should be trying to implementing a lestyle, not a aposlose weight quickapos hack. When you start on day one, ask yourself could you see yourself doing the same on day  or day   Because to lose weight and live a healthy and well balanced lestyle, whatever way you go about it needs be sustainable in the long term. title: married masseuse set up phone
story: Married masseuse set up phone camera in treatment room to film client stripping offTamas Dominko, , is seeking help for his “compulsive sexual behaviour” after he set up a phone to film a customer undressing before her massage at a parlour in west LondonMasseuse Tamas Dominko set up a phone to film a customer stripping Image: Phil HarrisByAdela WhittinghamCourt Reporter:,  Jan A married masseuse set up a phone on a treatment room shelf in an attempt to film a customer stripping naked. Tamas Dominko, , was caught out by the client who spotted the device as she went to get changed for the treatment - and turned it to face away from her before replacing it. After the treatment, she moved the phone again while dressing, then checked the screen to see it was still recording and had captured the massage. Ealing Magistrates’ Court heard the woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons, felt threatened after seeing the phone at a massage parlour in west London. She said in a statement she did not know how to deal with the discovery and spent the massage in fear there would be an altercation. Prosecutor Maya Arputham said: The defendant was in a massage centre as a contractor. He gets clients and they come in hourly for massages. This complainant comes in, she has been coming for three years and he has dealt with her before. On that day she realised something was very wrong. She sees a phone on a shelf, she turns the phone and undresses herself. She continued with the massage. Afterwards she looked at the phone and it was still recording and she was shocked. She took the phone from the shelf and went directly to the receptionist. In a statement, the victim said: It made me feel quite shocked and threatened through the appointment. I didnapost know how to deal with it in the massage and felt incredibly vulnerable as I was stuck in the room with Tamas almost completely naked and feared some altercation was coming.” Tamasin Graham, defending, said the father-of-one is seeking help for his “compulsive sexual behaviour” after the incident in July last year and has ended his career as a masseuse. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He now works as a kitchen porter, the court heard. She said: We are here for one specic incident and I have not seen any evidence to suggest police are investigating anything any further. This is something Mr Dominko, in his own words to me earlier, will have to live with for the rest of his le. He speaks about feeling shame and regret about what happened. He understands that itaposs completely unacceptable.  Chair of the bench Rupert Holderness said: It is a serious matter - people do go to prison for this sort of thing and I think you need to be awareyou were to be convicted of anything like this again you would face a very real prospect of going to prison despite the impact it would have on your we and daughter. Dominko, of Teddington, south west London, admitted a single count of voyeurism and was given a -month community order and ordered to carry out a sex offenders programme, rehabilitation activities and  hours of unpaid work. He must also pay costs, including £ compensation to the victim, of £.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: more brits seek vegan alternatives
story: More Brits seek vegan alternatives to everything from milk to skincare and even wineNearly half of Brits say they would like to try more animal-free products where possible - with one in six willing to give vegan skincare a goSix in ten Brits arent even aware that vegan skincare products exist Image: Skin Proud SWNSByAndrew Young:,  Jan | commentsBrits are seeking out vegan alternatives for milk, skincare - and even wine, according to research. A study of , adults found that while only  percent consider themselves to be completely vegan,  percent would like to try animal-free products where possible. Of those,  percent are concerned about the environmental impact of using non-vegan items, while  percent worry about animal welfare. As a result, many look for plant-based alternatives for skincare , make-upand leather accessories . It also emerged that one in six are more willing to try vegan skincare products than plant-based milk - with the same percentage of people claiming cowsapos milk negatively effects their skin. These issues include dry skin , acneand puffiness .  But almost six in ten adults claim they don’t even know that vegan skincare exists - with the price , natural ingredientsand whether it is cruelty-free , among the top considerations when buying beauty products.Of those who do look for vegan skincare products,  percent do so as it’s good for the planet, while  percent prefer that animals are unharmed during the production. Nora Zukauskaite, spokeswoman for vegan skincare brand Skin Proud, which commissioned the study to mark its Cowfunding campaign this Veganuary, said: “The study shows how vegan alternatives are on the rise, but there are still some who are hesitant to make the change.“It’s sad to see so few people know how dairy cows fare when it comes to farming. “It can be both emotionally and physically harmful to the animals, as well as have a devastating impact on the environment. “At Skin Proud, we want to encourage people to incorporate more alternatives into their daily lives, from clothes to skincare, through simple and easy changes, and help with our simple and affordable vegan skincare products. “Interestingly, women are more likely to try alternatives to men, but this is still a good start in the right direction. “Our hope in  is that vegan options should become the first and only consumer choice for skincare and beauty products, to help with animal and environmental impacts.” The study also found one in five adults would be willing to switch to an alternative milk choicethey knew more about the health benefits.  But a fth have never tried anything other than cows’ milk - because they fear that plant-based alternatives may taste “weird”. And  percent havenapost tasted an alternative due to the price, according to the OnePoll study. Almost half of adults are unaware of the impact of dairy farming on cows - but of the  percent who are, more than half said knowing this makes them more inclined to try dairy-free milk alternatives. Nora Zukauskaite added: “We are committed to being vegan and cruelty-free, and are PETA certied. “We are working to help save the cows in the UK and US, with our Cowfunding campaign to protect cows and their rights in the UK and US, with a portion of sales from our products across Veganuary being donated to the Animal Equality charity who help reduce the suffering of animals.” Skin Proud’s Cowfunding campaign will see them donate  percent of online profits across January to help reduce the suffering of animals in the UK and US. *Skin Proud is available from Boots, both in store and online. news uk-news mum-numb-after-inquest-finds-"Paige Boltons mum Cherie Rangeley reacts after inquestByJames Campbell:,  Jan  The mum of a schoolgirl found locked in a bathroom dying alongside her dad after a tragic house fire has said her daughter was murdered by her father. An inquest into the deaths of Garry Bolton and his daughter Paige, , was concluded on Monday with assistant coroner Ian Sprakes delivering a narrative verdict, Hull Live reports. He said: “On January , , Garry Bolton and Paige Bolton died at  Wensley Avenue in Hull between approximately .am and am due to the effects of inhalation of products of combustion and carbon monoxide poisoning due to the effects of a smouldering fire probably deliberately started that morning.” Garry and Paige died in the fire in the early hours of January , , at the house in north Hull, where they lived. But Paige’s mum Cherie Rangeley says the conclusion has left her with few answers and she believes a more definitive short form conclusion should have been delivered. She said she feels numb and like she has no closure. “For Paige it wasn’t suicide, Garry murdered my little girl,” she said. “There is no closure really. He didn’t have to take my little girl. If you want to kill yourself then fine but he didn’t have to take Paige. “I feel numb and didn’t really get the answers I was hoping for. I’m not any nearer where I feel I’m supposed to be. “I would have preferred a conclusion of suicide for Garry and unlawful killing for Paige rather than a narrative verdict. “But with Garry’s family there too I guess he has to see it from both sides.”  Cherie, who was with Garry for  years, also feels there was little said about Paige at the inquest. She said: “There was nothing really about Paige and how she felt. At the end of the day Garry took his own le and that of Paige which he had no right or need to do. “Paige was cheeky but also shy. But once she got to know you there was no shutting her up. “I loved her so much and loved buying her things.”  Cherie says Paige was quite a complex character but knew how much her family loved her. “Paige loved to play and we would go to a nearby basketball court and she would roller skate,” she said. “She loved being silly around me and we had a lot of fun. “But she was also delicate and could get very scared. I’m sure she knew what was going on that night and I dread to think what she went through. “But she knew how much she was loved. She rarely said she loved me but she would show it in other ways. “I just miss Paige being Paige and being able to hold her. I also miss her beautul smile.”  Cherie says it is still very hard and she struggles still every day. “Christmas was hard,” she said. “I started thinking I need to buy Paige a present and then realised she was gone. The inquest previously heard how Garry and Cherie had twins Paige and Ethan in  through IVF treatment. Sadly, Ethan died of a heart defect aged just six months, which devastated Garry and Cherie. Paige’s ashes have now been laid beside Ethan which makes Cherie’s visits to the graveside even more dficult. “I find it very hard visiting the grave as Paige really looked after Ethan’s headstone,” Cherie said “She would clean it every time we went there and would leave toys for Ethan. “Now she is not there to do it but, instead, lies next to Ethan. Paige was killed by her dad Garry in a murder-suicide in which he set fire to their home and locked them both inside, the coroner concluded on Monday. Mr Sprakes said he believed Garry Bolton had probably deliberately started the fire, with no logical explanation for the fire having been started accidentally.  Fire crews had to break into the property using a saw and then discovered the two victims lying together in the bathtub. Garry had locked the front door and made access inside dficult, the inquest heard, and no attempt had been made to contact the emergency services. Returning a narrative conclusion to the inquest, which started back in August, Mr Sprakes also referenced chilling texts sent by Paige to her grandmother before she died saying: Daddy is scaring me. Mr Bolton had also written a note expressing self-harm, the inquest heard. During proceedings in August, Mr Sprakes mentioned text messages Garry had sent to former partner Cherie, which he decided not to read out, which he said “amounted to a suicide note”. The inquest had heard how Garry’s mental health seemed to have deteriorated, having already suffered from anxiety, low self-esteem and paranoia.  Independent fire investigator Dr Will Hutchinson carried out an investigation into the blaze and he had also given evidence to the inquest. He had said it was a smouldering fire which meant it took a number of hours to develop. He also indicated such a fire would produce lethal levels of carbon monoxide almost immediately, which could take effect in a matter of minutes. The smoke alarm was also not working, but he could not say for sure whether the fire had been caused accidentally or deliberately. However, Humberside Fire and Rescue Service station manager Richard Gibson believed the cause was deliberate. He said: “I believe the ignition was due to an unspecied naked flame. “As the seat of the fire was in the centre of the bed, it leads me to believe it was deliberate.” Mr Sprakes delivered a narrative verdict. He said: “On January , , Garry Bolton and Paige Bolton died at  Wensley Avenue in Hull between approximately .am and am due to the effects of inhalation of products of combustion and carbon monoxide poisoning due to the effects of a smouldering fire probably deliberately started that morning.” Mr Sprakes went on to offer his condolences to Paige’s mum and the sister and mother of Garry who were all in court. He said: “I express my sincere condolences to the families of Garry and Paige Bolton. “This is a very sad and, indeed, tragic event. There are very few words I can say to relieve the pain and anguish for a truly tragic event.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON MurderMental healthInquests" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum two 37 goes blind
story: Mum-of-two, , goes blind every time she has a hot shower - and it was first sign of diseaseMum-of-two Samantha Stevens suffers with a form of neurological disease multiple sclerosis and says the first sign of the illness was when she suddenly lost her eyesight every time she showered at homeMum-of-two Samantha Stevens says the first sign pointing to her having was when she started losing her eyesight in the shower Image: Liverpool ECHOByAaron CurranRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments A mum-of-two who loses her eyesight every time she has a hot shower says the visual disturbance was the first sign of multiple sclerosis. Samantha Stevens. , has relapse remitting MS, an incurable neurological condition which involves the immune system attacking nerves in the brain and spinal cord. She was first diagnosed with the lelong disease in  when her daughter was just a year old, Liverpool Echo reports. The ailment - which causes tiredness, vision problems and issues with balance or walking - manested in Samanthaaposs case with blindness whenever her core temperature rose too high.She would lose her eyesight completely in one eye whenever she took a hot shower and during hot summer days.Have your say on Samanthaaposs story in the comment section Speaking to the Liverpool Echo, she said: My daughter was a year old and I just lost sight in one of my eyes, I think MS can quite often present with visual disturbances. My auntie struggled with MS for a long time and she got to the point where she lost mobility in her arms and legs and I saw that growing up, so my first thought was aposoh no am I going to end up bed riddenapos as many with the condition do. I had an MRI scan and a lumbar puncture to confirm my diagnosis, thereaposs a lot of invisible symptomsI have a hot shower, I lose my eyesight, in the summeritaposs too warm, I lose my eyesight. I am fortunate that when my core temperature goes back to normal I do regain my sight. The Multiple Sclerosis society estimates that there are over , people with MS in the UK, and that nearly  people are newly diagnosed each year. Samantha, from Newton-le-Willows, now cares for her two daughters on her own, despite her condition progressing further requiring her to use a walking stick. She said: A lot of the time, with the relapses, you will have a problem and your immune system will sort of repair itself, but now that Iaposm in the progressive stage of my disease, there isnapost any repair now. I have extra aids at home, extra rails and equipment in the bathroom to help me with my showers and that sort of thing. The mum-of-two believes her devastating condition has strengthened her relationship with her two daughters aged  and . She said: There are small things like struggling to fill in a form when my kids bring them home from school because I struggle to hold a pen. My kids actually help quite a lot with cooking, and lting pans from the cooker to the sink and so on. Theyaposve almost taken on sort of a careraposs role which is rubbish because you hope your children will have as much as a childhood as they can. My older daughter understands the disease and its effect and she definitely worries, but Iaposd say it affects our relationship positively because I think they have a lot of admiration for me and what I have to do without the help of her their dad. He left when things got bad to have a better le without the burden of me I suppose, so it is just me and the girls.  Samantha is on a waiting list for NHS treatment but believes her best hope is to travel abroad and receive experimental stem cell treatment, that she claims to have up to a % success rate in treating her condition.She said: It is a risky and potentially dangerous procedure but I really don’t have many options. If there’s even a small chance that my disease progression can be stopped I’m willing to take the risk.Samantha is raising money to help fund her trip for treatment, you can donate via her GoFundMe page.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSImmune systemMultiple sclerosisDisabilityParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: my familys history shows mining
story: My familys history shows that mining has been in my blood for almost  yearsPaul Routledge says that his forebear Joseph Routledge, born in Durham in , was a miner, living in Shinclfe and married to Alice, nee Longstaff. Longstaffe is the writers middle nameMiners strike in  Image: Daily RecordopinionByPaul Routledge:,  Jan | commentsIt was something of a mystery why I was attracted to the cause of the miners. True, the National Union of Mineworkers was never out of the headlines in the Seventies and Eighties when I was Labour Editor of The Times. But that didn’t quite explain why I felt at home with them. Now I learn that it’s been in my blood for nigh on  years. The  Census shows my forebear Joseph Routledge, born in Durham in , was a miner, living in Shinclfe and married to Alice, nee Longstaff. Longstaffe is my middle name. I don’t know where the “e” came from.  Joseph and his family became Mormons and for a time he emigrated to Salt Lake City in the USA before ing, disillusioned, to his native county. Joseph went back into mining, studied hard and gained a manager’s certicate and was in charge of Ryhope colliery, Sunderland, for at least  years. Joseph was also the co-inventor of a safety lamp for use underground, and must have been quite well thought-of despite being the boss, credited with trying to keep the miners happy. He died in , and his widow, Alice,  years later. They are both commemorated in a stained-glass window in St Paul’s Church, Ryhope. Remarkable. I was dimly aware of these facts before, in relation to a novel by the Sunderland writer Glenda Craig. But I am indebted to the Routledge Clan Society, of which I am now a member, and its newsletter, The Blackmail, for the full story. No, I don’t know why they call it that – something  to find out. Maybe it’s what we paid the reivers who stole our cattle when we lived on the Scottish borders. news uk-news parents-livid-after--year-"Sneyd Green: Children shown bizarre video in RE classByAimi Redfern:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe parents of an eleven-year-old student are up in arms after their son’s RE class was shown a video featuring a cartoon of a sex toy covered in razor blades. The shocking video, which also includes frequent bad language, was shown to year  pupils as part of the religious studies syllabus at Excel Academy, in Sneyd Green, Stoke-on-Trent. It was included as part of a lesson on religious symbols last week and showed two cartoon figures discussing the Taoist aposyin and yangapos symbol and what the best and worst things in the world they could imagine were. One character thinks of a cheese toastie as the best thing in the world and a sex toy covered in razor blades as a depiction of something evil. The school says the Youtube video was shown by a substitute teacher, who had used the wrong video link. It says the video was identied as being inappropriate when played and wonapost be used again. But pupil River Maddocks told Stoke-on-Trent Live the teacher had told the class the video contained offensive language before it was shown.The first swear word appears on-screen at  seconds and an image of Jesus Christ reading Playboy magazine appears at  seconds. At  seconds, the F-word is spoken. The sex toy imagery is not until more than two-and-a-half minutes into the four-minute-long video. River, , who is a Christian, said he was shocked by the content and scribbled down the name of the film so he could tell his mum and dad.  His parents, Leah and Eden Maddocks, of Smallthorne, were horried when they watched the video for themselves. Leah, aged , said: When River first told us about it we thought he must be exaggerating, but when we watched it, it was even worse than we thought. Whoever decided to show that in a lesson must not have watched it properly beforehand. Itaposs not just the bad language or the fact it is offensive to every faith going - there is a part with a cartoon depiction of something which they shouldnapost even know about at their age. When we watched it we were mortied. I donapost think it is suitable to be shown to any age group in a school. Posted to YouTube by the Sam OaposNella Academy, the expletive-ridden film is called Where Religious Symbols Come From ­- That Happened Thursday and features stickmen characters giving an explanation of where the symbols adopted by ious world religions originate. River said he was astonished to be shown the video during a lesson. He said: We were revising for an RE test and doing religious symbols. The teacher, who isnapost our normal teacher, said he had a video to show uswe needed help with it. I was shocked when I saw it. All the other kids were laughing. Itaposs really not appropriate for a school.  Riveraposs dad Eden, , added: As soon as he mentioned it I was fuming, but when we sat and watched it, it was even worse than I thought. The world is going bananasthat can be shown in a school. An Alpha Academies Trust spokesperson said: A supply teacher used an incorrect video link which was identied as being inappropriate when played and will not be used again. More stringent checks will be made moving forward to ensure this does not happen again.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Jesus of NazarethYouTubeEducationSchoolsToysSex toys" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pensioner 87 waits 10 hours
story: Pensioner, , waits  hours in an ambulance outside hospital after suffering strokeJoanne Freeman, , was "screaming in agony" but treatment at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf for her stroke - likely caused by blood clots thanks to Covid - didnt start for  hoursJoanne Freeman, , was left outside hospital for  hours after suffering a strokeByZara PereiraRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan | comments An elderly dementia patient waited  hours outside a hospital after suffering a stroke. Joanne Freeman, , had contracted coronavirus two weeks earlier which had likely caused blood clots leading to the le-threatening medical condition when blood is cut off from the brain.She arrived at the University Hospital of Wales in Cardf at noon last Thursday but was moved to three dferent ambulances as paramedics finished their sht.The pensioner was screaming in agony and her hands were over her eyes when her family called for an ambulance around .am, a close relative said, reports Wales Online. She was saying her head was absolutely killing her. She lives by herself but has a carer who comes in four times a day who told us she was very distressed, they explained.Have you faced similar delays at hospital  Let us know at webnews@mirror Attempts were made to give Mrs Freeman paracetamol and other medication but she couldnapost take them or open her eyes. Mrs Freeman was eventually given an IV drip and her family reached the hospital but had to wait outside in the ambulance. The family member said she felt sorry for the paramedics as they changed shts, with one allegedly revealing there were  standing calls but none could be attended to as all ambulances were in use. They said there were a total of  waiting outside the hospital with patients inside. Mrs Freeman was allegedly still being given paracetamol once sheaposd been admitted and the relativeaposs brother-in-law had to raise his voice to get things sorted and a scan arranged, they claimed.  He had to ask them to put fresh bedding on and change the dressing on her back - nothing was given, we had to prompt them, they continued. At midnight -  hours after Mrs Freeman was first struck ill - her family was finally told sheaposd suffered a stroke and at am she was moved to a specialist ward. Referring to the stroke likely stemming from blood clots caused by Covid, the relative said: We had been waiting for her booster for ages but as itaposs a home visit she needs, there is a delay. Mrs Freeman caught Covid from one of her carers and came out of isolation on December . Her relative said: Itaposs just diabolical in there. I felt like I was in a third world country. You wouldnapost treat a dog like that. They were saying she needs to drink water yet ignoring that she couldnapost even hold a cup up.  We had to ask them for a drip. I know itaposs because they are understaffed because of Covid so lack a lot of staff and resources but to think Joanne was treated as an urgent patient but still didnapost get seen for  hours is crazy. What baffles me is how she kept saying how much pain she was in and was having a stroke but she wasnapost seen for that amount of time. If it was a -year-old person, would they be treated in the same way  Or is it because thereaposs not space at the hospital  Itaposs just ludicrous. I feel like I was leaving her le in danger by leaving her in their care. It never used to be like that.  A spokesperson for Cardf and Vale University Health Board, said: “We sincerely apologise for the delays and experience Joanne has received during this time. Health and social care services across Cardf and the Vale of Glamorgan are experiencing signicant and sustained pressures which is leading to delays in care provision and the timely discharge of patients from hospital.This, in turn, is impacting on patient flow within our hospital and waiting times in our Emergency Unit. Our focus remains on patient care and our staff are working tirelessly to see patients in a timely manner dependent on their healthcare needs.While we are under these extreme pressures, we would ask the public thatthey donapost have a le-threatening emergency to please call CAV   on     so we can assess and direct patients appropriately. ”Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON ParacetamolHospitalsMental healthCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-george-left-confused-annoyed-"Prince William discusses George litter picking at schoolByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments After a long and no doubt fun-filled Christmas holiday, Prince George and Princess Charlotte are due back at school today.The sibling duo attends the private Thomasaposs School in Battersea, South London, and today marks the start of the lent term.George, the oldest child of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and third in line to the throne, is now in Year  having started at the school in .And while it seems the young prince enjoys his lessons, there was apparently one school activity he took part in that left him confused and annoyed. And his dad Prince William revealed that activity was carrying out litter picking sessions, which left his son frustrated about the state of the planet. Speaking to a BBC podcast last year, William ulged: So George at school recently has been doing litter picking and I didnapost realise but talking to him the other day he was already showing that he was getting a bit confused and a bit sort of annoyed by the fact they went out litter picking one day and then the very next day they did the same route, same time and pretty much all the same litter they picked up back again.And I think that for him he was trying to understand how and where it all came from. He couldnapost understand, heaposs like, aposwell, we cleaned this. Why has it not gone away ’  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. William has been very vocal in the past  months about turning the tide on climate change and environmental problems.And heaposs previously said that he was concerned that George and his generation might still be talking about climate change in decades to come.  He added: But it shouldnapost be that thereaposs a third-generation now coming along having to ramp it up even more. And you know, for me, it would be an absolute disasterGeorge is sat here talking to you or your successor, you know in like  years time, whatever, still saying the same thing, because by then we will be too late.  It is thought that George and Charlotteaposs younger brother Prince Louis will join them at the same school in September after he turns four in April.As part of William and Kateaposs wishes to give them as normal an upbringing as possible, as soon as they walk through the school gates their kids are treated like any other child.And this means they must do what teachers tell them and follow the schoolaposs most important rule - just like everyone . Its website states: As you would expect of any Thomasaposs school, the most important school rule is aposBe Kindapos. news uk-news queens-favourite-fast-food-revealed-"Foodhub creates the Maamburger in honour of the QueenByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The Queenaposs favourite aposfast-foodapos has been revealed by one of her former chefs - and itaposs not a McDonaldaposs Big Mac or a KFC bargain bucket.The -year-old monarch is known to enjoy the occasional potted shrimp and chocolate cake, but her biggest guilty pleasure is said to be venison burgers eaten with a kne and fork. Ex-royal cook Darren McGrady says HM prefers to flavour the game meat with cranberries rather than relish or secret sauce but never has it sandwiched between a bread bun. Instead, she eats it naked on the plate.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  Speaking to Insider last year, Mr McGrady said: “It always tickled me at Balmoral, we would make our own burgers. They would shoot deer, and we would do venison burgers.“There’d be gorgeous cranberry…stuffed into them, but we never set buns out. He went on to say: Her Majestyaposs Victorian upbringing dictates that the only thing you would pick up and eat with your fingers is afternoon tea. They would have burgers, but not the buns. So they would eat it with their kne and fork. The Queen holidays at the Balmoral estate in Scotland almost every August or September - last year for the first time in decades without Prince Philip, following his death in April.Mr McGrady worked as head chef at Buckingham Palace from  until , making food for Prince William and Harry, as well as Princess Diana. He also said the monarch hates pizza and during his time in her service, not a single pizza was ever served.  When he wasnapost prepping venison patties, the top chef was usually cooking up traditional French foods, he added. Following the chefaposs revelation in August, online takeaway service Foodhub created the aposMaaposamburgerapos. news uk-news three-most-common-mistakes-people-"Nadhim Zahawi says free lateral flows will not be scrappedByAntony Thrower:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsAn AE doctor has shared the most common mistakes he has found people make when taking lateral flow tests. Millions of Brits have made taking the tests part of their everyday lives to help prevent the spread of Covid infections. Dr Nathan, a doctor in London, says some people are testing themselves incorrectly and may be inadvertently going out while positive for the virus. He says the three most common mistakes are failing to spot positives, not reading the instructions and mixing up the best way to conduct the test, Manchester Evening News reports. Dr Nathan said: “Any positive line within  minutes, evenit is so faint that it is barely visible, equals a positive result, he said. “However,a faint line appears after  minutes, this can be ignored.” He added: “Don’t forget to avoid eating or drinking for at least  minutes before, to blow your nose and to wash your hands!”  “You should always follow the enclosed instructions, he continued. “If the test advises doing a throat and nose swab, do this. If it advises a nose swab only, do this. “That being said, there are some anecdotal reports of people getting a positive throat swab and a negative nose swab, and later developing symptoms and a positive PCR.”Dr Nathan who shares advice about Covid on his Instagram, @expedition_doctor. It comes as a new rule change is set to come into effect tomorrow, as the government works on keeping on top of coronavirus case numbers.There have been dficulties keeping track of case numbers in recent weeks due to shortages of lateral flow testsand polymerase chain reactiontests.Despite this, case numbers have remained high and have reached record levels since the Omicron iant took a hold on the country.  The UKaposs official Covid death toll passed , on Saturday January . Currently, people who test positive for Covid with no symptoms on a lateral flow test are required to take a PCR to confirm their status. This will change from January . They will still have to isolate for at least seven days, but only from the date of their positive lateral flow test. title: tory private health deal branded
story: Tory private health deal branded waste of money as experts fear no help for NHSCampaigner Dr John Lister, of Keep Our NHS Public, said the new deal showed ministers and NHS England had learned nothing from the sums wasted on unused private capacity in Ambulances parked outside Queens Hospital in Romford, East London Image: Marcin Nowak LNPByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Jan | comments A Tory deal to pay private hospitals millions to take NHS patients has been blasted as a huge waste of public money. Critics condemned the three-month arrangement with  health care firms which is intended to offer cancer surgery and urgent care to NHS truststhey are overwhelmed by Covid cases.Experts, campaigners and trade unions believe the new deal, backed by undisclosed amounts of taxpayers’ cash, will line multinational firms’ pockets and care for very few NHS patients.They say private hospitals can only take on extra patients by poaching medics from the NHS, which needs , more staff.At least  NHS trusts stretched to the limits have declared critical incidents in recent days.  In the first year of the pandemic, NHS England signed contracts worth more than £billion with private hospital firms. Yet they delivered less than .% of the nation’s Covid care and took on fewer NHS patients than the year before, said the Centre for Health and the Public Interest think tank. Campaigner Dr John Lister, of Keep Our NHS Public, said the new deal showed ministers and NHS England had learned nothing from the sums wasted on unused private capacity in . The health policy academic said: “Private hospitals can only take on additional NHS patients by poaching additional staff trained, and employed, by the NHS.” He said: “Tory ministers now prefer to squander more millions on short-term stop-gap deals with profit-seeking private hospitals than invest in reopening the ­thousands of NHS beds.”  Cat Hobbs, of campaign group We Own It, said decades of under funding has stretched the NHS to its limit and this is now an excuse to hand out more private contracts. “Not only does this open the door to further privatisation of our NHS, it’s also a huge waste of public money.” But Health Secretary Sajid Javid said the agreement showed the collaboration across our health care services to create an extra safeguard that ensures people can continue to get the care they need.The UK has one of the fewest hospital beds-per-head of ­population of almost any developed nation. NHS England said more than , NHS day cases, almost . million surgical procedures and more than , diagnostic tests were carried out in the private sector in the past year.  The UK recorded , more confirmed Covid cases today and  more deaths.Weekly Covid hospitalisations are up % in the North East but in London, where Omicron first took off, hospital admissions in  are now down about a fth.NHS England chief operating officer Sir David Sloman said the new deal “means as many people as possible can continue to get the care they need”. title: uk weather forecast icy blast
story: UK weather forecast: Icy blast to freeze Brits with up to cm of snow to fall this weekThe UK is set for a north-south ide with frosty temperatures set for Scotland which could see see up to five centimetres of snow fall while it will be milder in the south westThere could be up to five centimetres snow falling in Scotland Image: Andrew McCaren LNPByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | comments Brits will need to wrap up warm with more frosty weather predicted with temperatures dropping below zero and up to five centimetres of snow expected to fall.Maps from WXCharts show that the Atlantic pressure system that brought cold weather and snow from Greenland at the start of the month will continue to hit the UK, although it will not be as extreme. There will also be a north-south ide with temperatures hovering around zero and dropping as low as -C on Tuesday morning, while milder temperatures and rain is predicted for the south west of England. Met Office forecaster Alex Deaking said:In Scotland and Northern Ireland there’s a hint of blue on the charts and so certainly in rural areas and hills there will be pockets of frost. Most towns and cities just about staying above but we are in the colder air here further south with the cloud and the rain we are a long way from freezing with town in the south west perhaps staying in double digits.  Monday was a washout for much of the country with plenty of rain but Tuesday should be brighter and then the mercury will drop again in the evening. Temperatures will tumble on Tuesday evening so again that blue hue on the charts suggesting frost before midnight in the Midlands, South Wales and further south will see a frost developing and some fog patches which could be slow to clear on Wednesday, said Mr Deakin. More clouds across the North West and the Highlands but for most Wednesday is a fine winters day with some sparkling sunshine and light winds. Start with a frost but by the afternoon temperatures ticking up to about the average of C or C.  There was a warning though that it could be a lot colderthe fog doesnapost lt. “Butfog sticks then it will be dficult for the temperatures to get much above freezing,” added Mr Deakin.The weather pattern is expected to continue next week with typical frost for the time of the year.  The Met Office stated: A continuation of largely settled conditions is most likely as we head into the middle of January with high pressure remaining in charge across the south of the country. Most areas are set to be dry with any spells of rain and stronger winds likely to be restricted to northern parts of the country. The settled weather will bring widespread overnight frost as well as fog patches, these sometimes freezing. UK forecast for the next  days Today: Blustery showers in west and north Scotland, slowly easing. Rain, drizzle and low cloud across southern areas, where it will be mild. However sunnier skies in central parts of the UK should follow to all but some southern counties later. Tonight: Windy across northern Scotland, with patchy rain and fairly mild. Elsewhere dry, patchy cloud in some central and western parts but clear where with frost and patchy rural fog. Wednesday: Southern and central areas mostly sunny with light winds, after any fog clears, temperatures mostly near average before frost and fog s after dark. Northern Scotland, windy with patchy rain. Outlook for Thursday to Saturday: Settled but colder in the south with fog and low cloud becoming more widespread and stubborn to clear. Milder further north with rain and stronger winds at first. news us-news ex-property-tycoon-turned-convicted-"Robert Durst: Convicted murder confirmed dead by lawyerByChristopher BucktinUnited States Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Billionaire real estate scion and long suspected serial killer recently convicted in his friendaposs murder, Robert Durst, has died.The American property heir hit the headlines when he unwittingly confessed in an HBO crime documentary series about himself.Durstaposs lawyer, Chip Lewis, confirmed he died at the San Joaquin General Hospital while in the custody of the Calornia Department of Corrections.He said: “We understand that his death was due to natural causes associated with the litany of medical issues we had repeatedly reported to the court over the last couple of years. We will issue no further statements and will not entertain any questions out of respect.”  His health had been failing for some time.Late last year he was placed on a ventilator after testing positive for COVID-. He had also battled bladder cancer. Durst was sentenced to le in prison in October for the execution-style killing of his longtime confidant Susan Berman, and soon after he was indicted for the  murder of his we, Kathleen Durst. The New York native was born into one of New York’s wealthiest families but became best known over the disappearance of his we and the murders of his best friend. Durst, whose family have owned a series of New York skyscrapers, including an investment in the World Trade Centre, was investigated after a recording of him confessing was used in the  HBO documentary series The Jinx.During filming, he said into a hot mic, “killed them all, of course.”He was serving a seven-year sentence on a firearms charge as he was arrested and tried for Berman’s murder. He was acquitted of murdering a neighbour, Morris Black, in , whom Durst said he killed in self-defence. title: man called kovid used love
story: Man called Kovid used to love unique name - now people think he changed it as a jokeA man named Kovid Kapoor previously thought his first name was unusual and cool, but he now finds himself the centre of endless jokes about the Covid- pandemicKovid Kapoor is embracing the unfortunate similarity between his name and the global pandemic Image: Handout AFP via Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writerTaniya Dutta:,  Jan | commentsThose of us with unusual names know that our monikers are like marmite - we either love how odd they are, or we canapost stand them. But one man has found himself experiencing both ends of the spectrum after the Covid- pandemic took him from embracing his unique name to being the butt of endless jokes. Kovid Kapoor, from Bangalore, Karnataka, India, always thought his name was special - until early  when he realised he now shares his name with a virus that has caused a global health crisis. The -year-old trip agency owner said: It is crazy how I am getting all this attention for my name.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Before the pandemic, Iaposve always thought it was a unique name. I have met just one another Kovid in college and we instantly connected because I never found anyone with the same name. Kovidaposs name was chosen by his mum after she saw it in a religious hymn and the word - which is spelt with a soft aposdapos - means scholar in Hindi. And although the pandemic has made him second guess his love for his name, Kovid says heaposs embracing the hilarity of the situation as best he can.  He added: I was amused when the WHO first announced Covid in . Friends and relatives started sharing the reports with me. It was surprising at first. For three months straight, my name was on TV every day although with a slight spelling dference. It felt great. My mother was equally amused. But as the pandemic spread, Kovid found that more people began to think he was lying about his name - or that heaposd changed it for a joke. In one hilarious instance, Kovidaposs friends ordered a personalised cake for his th birthday last year, but after thinking the message was a joke, the baker changed his name to aposCovidapos. The man has also had baristas in coffee shops stare at him bemused when he gives them his name and has been laughed at by security officials. He said: People really find it amusing, they think I am joking or have changed the name. I have changed my Twitter bio to aposmy name is Kovid and I am not a virus.apos Kovid is making the best out of the awkward situation though and hopes the increased interest in his name will help bring more traffic to the trip agency that he owns. Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news weird-news mcdonalds-worker-shares-how-makes-"McDonald’s worker shares how he serves those that demand ‘fresh fries’ByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience WriterRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Jan | commentsWe all love a trip to McDonaldaposs. From a classic Big Mac to the new vegan McPlant, thereaposs something for all of us. And itaposs hard to argue that their salty golden French Fries arenapost better than other chains - although, of course, that is subject to personal choice. One McDonaldaposs worker went viral after releasing a video showing how he treats rude customers who demand fresh fries.Deandre Byars, who claims to work at the fast-food restaurant, told viewers to stop being rude to staff in a now-viral TikTok video on the , where heaposs known as @dresav.In the clip, he jokily revealed what happens when you demand fresh fries at McDonaldaposs.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Instead of making a fresh batch, as you may have expected, Deandre simply reheats them. He begins by throwing the cooked chips that are sat in a heating station back into a frying basket to dip them in the oil for a quick fry. He leaves it in there for a few seconds before taking them out and putting them back into the packaging. Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and thousands of comments from ided viewers. One person said: How is asking for fresh fries rude  I swear people love to do the bare minimum, to which Deandre replied saying: Demanding and asking are two dferent things. Another joked: “Then you have to remake them because we all know they’re not fresh and complain, so you’re really playing yourself. A third person said reheating the fries is unsafe because the salt ruins the oil. But surprisingly, the majority of people didnapost seem to care as long as their chips were warm. Lol thataposs fine as long as theyaposre hot, one said.  Another added: Literally as long as they arenapost cold, tough or soggy [I donapost care]. If that fixes it then Iaposm cool with it. While someone  advised: Always ask for fries with no salt and they will a hundred per cent be fresh! Bring your own salt! This isnapost the first time a McDonaldaposs employee has shared store secrets.Katie, known as @katieeclarkee on TikTok, has explained why they take your picture when youaposre using the drive-thru.During her sht, she showed viewers the drive-thru camera and demonstrated how it works.Take a look here. Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. news weird-news my-mums-nursery-school-teacher-"Tiktoker reacts to mums list of preschoolers namesByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan | commentsYour name is often the first piece of information someone learns about you, which is why itaposs so important as a parent you pick a good one. But one woman couldnapost help but laugh when her mum, a teacher, reeled off the names of the children in her class. Shay went viral on TikTok after she posted a video reacting to names like Bram and Richard.Posting on her account, @shayymonet, she said: Another school year, another batch of names to judge.The first name, Bram, didnapost get much of a reaction from Shay. Bram  she said, to which her mum confirmed: Yes Bram. Bram with a B. Bram. Bram. Got it, Shay replied.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Then there was Emmett, Atticus, and Jordan, all of which got very little reaction. But when her mum says that one of the children in this yearaposs class is called Richard, she burst out laughing. RICHARD! Heaposs four  she exclaimed, to which her mum confirms with a yes. Her mum continues reading out the names: Annabelle, Adele, Alina and then Ryan, which gets a laugh but she canapost explain why. Then thereaposs Everleigh, which her mum says is spelt like Ever-lay and Shay says, Oh, like L-E-I-G-H...L-M-N-O-P  She laughs again at the end as she recalls there are kids called Bram and Richard. Since being posted, the video, which has been viewed more than . million times, has attracted more than , likes and , comments from people who shared their thoughts on the names. One person said: aposRichard  Heaposs  !apos No babe heaposs a -year-old father who came back for good measure. Another wrote: Bram is a very common name in the Netherlands! Does sound funny when you pronounce it in English though hahaha. A third commented: I used to think Annabelle was a cute name but the doll movie ruined that for me. Someone  said: Why is Richard so funny  I thought the other ones were more ridiculous. Others shared other unique names they had heard before, like Barnaby. One person revealed: At my kidaposs school, thereaposs a three-year-old called Barnaby. Who looks at a bay and thinks yes Barnby  My mum once had a girl in her class called STRAWBERRY, added another.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: seemingly innocent house sale 590k
story: Seemingly innocent house on sale for £k - with strip club hidden in the basementA five-bedroom property, located on a quiet cul-de-sac, is surprisingly equipped with booze-filled fridges, black booths, a pool table, neon signs, a large bar area and stripper poleThe home appears rather innocent Image: Jam Press Kohlmeyer RemodelingByLiam GilliverOpinion WriterRia Newman:,  Jan | comments An innocent seeming house with a secret nightclub and strip club hidden in the basement has gone on the market for £,. The property, which boasts five bedrooms and . bathrooms, is located in a quiet cul-de-sac in Indianapolis, US, and appears to be a regular family home from the outside.It features a large swimming pool and decent-size decking space, perfect for entertaining. Nothing seems suspicious when you enter the , square foot pad either. It is elegantly decorated with wooden accents throughout and has a grand dining table perfect for a family, which lies under an impressive chandelier.  Want an escape from the doom and gloom  Share your email for all the fun and heartwarming stories of the day from the Mirror However, potential buyers may be in for a bit of a shockthey head down to the basement - which has been converted into a nightclub complete with booze-filled fridges, black booths, a pool table, neon signs, a large bar area and space to dance. Thereaposs also a makesht strip club with a stage, dancing pole, disco ball and large viewing sofa. Viewers were stunned by the secret nightclub after pictures of the house were shared online. “I live just across the border in Illinois. That may really be the hottest club in Indiana, one person said.  Another added: “Business in the front, party in the back. Someone  commented: “Ultimate house for introverts, you can go out and stay in at the same time!”If partying isnapost for you, you might be interested in the striking two-bedroom house that went on the market for a much more affordable £,.The catch  The gothic octagon-shaped house is painted entirely black - both on the inside and outside. Owner Seth Goodman decided he liked the dark colours and redecorated the outside of his home after buying it last year, but hasnapost had any offers despite the low price.  I was interested and thought at first I was just going to flip the house, but after my home sold, I needed a place to live, Goodman told the Lincoln Courier.I wanted to make it more modern and after seeing the black roof, I thought why not go with black siding. From there we used black gutters, painted the deck black and changed the landscaping rocks to black.Which house would you want to buy  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON property newsViralNightclubs" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts from our Property Market newsletterSubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
